user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_shmem_try_map:
```c
static int metal_shmem_try_map(struct metal_page_size *ps, int fd, size_t size,
			       struct metal_io_region **result)
{
	size_t pages, page, phys_size;
	struct metal_io_region *io;
	metal_phys_addr_t *phys;
	uint8_t *virt;
	void *mem;
	int error;

	size = metal_align_up(size, ps->page_size);
	pages = size / ps->page_size;

	error = metal_map(fd, 0, size, 1, ps->mmap_flags, &mem);
	if (error) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
			  "failed to mmap shmem %ld,0x%x - %s\n",
			  size, ps->mmap_flags, strerror(-error));
		return error;
	}

	error = mlock(mem, size);
	if (error) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING, "failed to mlock shmem - %s\n",
			  strerror(errno));
	}

	phys_size = sizeof(*phys) * pages;
	phys = malloc(phys_size);
	if (!phys) {
		metal_unmap(mem, size);
		return -ENOMEM;
	}

	io = malloc(sizeof(*io));
	if (!io) {
		free(phys);
		metal_unmap(mem, size);
		return -ENOMEM;
	}

	if (_metal.pagemap_fd < 0) {
		phys[0] = 0;
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
		"shmem - failed to get va2pa mapping. use offset as pa.\n");
		metal_io_init(io, mem, phys, size, -1, 0, &metal_shmem_io_ops);
	} else {
		for (virt = mem, page = 0; page < pages; page++) {
			size_t offset = page * ps->page_size;

			error = metal_virt2phys(virt + offset, &phys[page]);
			if (error < 0)
				phys[page] = METAL_BAD_OFFSET;
		}
		metal_io_init(io, mem, phys, size, ps->page_shift, 0,
			&metal_shmem_io_ops);
	}
	*result = io;

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_shmem_try_map:
struct metal_io_region {
	void			*virt;      /**< base virtual address */
	const metal_phys_addr_t	*physmap;   /**< table of base physical address
						 of each of the pages in the I/O
						 region */
	size_t			size;       /**< size of the I/O region */
	unsigned long		page_shift; /**< page shift of I/O region */
	metal_phys_addr_t	page_mask;  /**< page mask of I/O region */
	unsigned int		mem_flags;  /**< memory attribute of the
						 I/O region */
	struct metal_io_ops	ops;        /**< I/O region operations */
}
...
typedef unsigned long metal_phys_addr_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: static int metal_shmem_try_map(struct metal_page_size *ps, int fd, size_t size,
explanation: I did not mark other pointer occurrences as suspicious because they are modified or used in ways that require a non-const target: - metal_phys_addr_t *phys is written to (phys[0] = 0; phys[page] = ...), so it cannot be a pointer-to-const. - void *mem is used as the region base (passed to mlock, metal_unmap and stored in the I/O region's virt field of type void *), so it must remain a non-const void *. - struct metal_io_region **result is an output parameter (the function assigns *result = io), so the pointee must be assignable and cannot be const-qualified here. - struct metal_io_region *io is allocated and initialized, then returned; it is intentionally mutable. - Other identifiers are scalars (size_t, int, etc.) and not subject to this rule. Therefore the only pointer candidates in this function that appear to be read-only and could reasonably be const-qualified are the incoming page-size parameter ps (it is only read) and the local virt pointer (used only to form addresses passed for translation), which is why they are reported for further investigation.
